chapter.title: Users and Roles
chapter.para: Users and roles form the basis of Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager authorization. Role-based access control allows coarse-grained job functions to be assigned to individual users. The Manager user abstraction is in turn heavily oriented towards the Active Directory concept of a user.

section.title: Roles
section.para: The rel="roles" link obtained from the entry point URI (see ) provides access to a static set of system roles. Each individual role elements contain the following:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: Globally unique identifier for this role
The role name (may be used as a more convenient identifier in any role-specific operations)
A free-text description of the role
A reference to the associated user (only present in the context of the role represented being assigned to an individual user)

section.screen:
GET /restapi-definition/roles HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<roles> <role id="00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001" href="/restapi-definition/roles/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001"> <name>SuperUser</name> <description>Roles management administrator</description> </role> <role id="00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000001" href="/restapi-definition/roles/00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000001"> <name>RHEVMUser</name> <description>RHEVM user</description> </role> <role id="00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000002" href="/restapi-definition/roles/00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000002"> <name>RHEVMPowerUser</name> <description>RHEVM power user</description> </role> <role id="00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000003" href="/restapi-definition/roles/00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000003"> <name>RHEVMVDIUser</name> <description>RHEVM VDI user</description> </role> </roles>

note.para: Because the global roles form a static set in Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager 2.2, the usual collection idioms are not followed in this case, i.e. a new role cannot be created via POST, nor can a role be destroyed via DELETE on the collection.

section.para: Any subset of the global roles set may be assigned to an individual user, as we shall see in the next section.

section.title: Role Permits
section.para: Each role contains a set of allowable actions, or permits, which are defined in . A role's permits are listed as a sub-collection:
section.screen:
GET /restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9/permits HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<permits> <permit id="1" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9/permits/1"> <name>CREATE_VM</name> <administrative>false</administrative> <role id="b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9"/> </permit> <permit id="4" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9/permits/4"> <name>VM_BASIC_OPERATIONS</name> <administrative>false</administrative> <role id="b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9"/> </permit> </permits>
section.para: A permit is assigned to a role when POSTed to the permits sub-collection. Use either an id= attribute or a name element to specify the permit to assign. For example:
section.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9/permits HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
<permit id="1"/>
HTTP/1.1 201 Created Content-Type: application/xml
<permits> <permit id="1" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9/permits/1"> <name>CREATE_VM</name> <administrative>false</administrative> <role id="b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9" href="/restapi-definition/roles/b67dfbe2-0dbc-41e4-86d3-a2fbef02cfa9"/> </permit> </permits>

section.title: Users
section.para: Users are exposed via a top-level collection, referenced by the rel="users" link. Individual user elements contain the following:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: Globally unique identifier for this user
The user principal name (may be used as a more convenient identifier when adding a new user)
A free-text name for the user
A free-text description of the user
A list of Active Directory groups for this user

section.screen:
GET /restapi-definition/users HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
<users> <user id="225f15cd-e891-434d-8262-a66808fcb9b1" href="/restapi-definition/users/225f15cd-e891-434d-8262-a66808fcb9b1"> <name>RHEV-M Admin</name> <actions/> <link rel="roles" href="/restapi-definition/users/225f15cd-e891-434d-8262-a66808fcb9b1/roles"/> <link rel="tags" href="/restapi-definition/users/225f15cd-e891-434d-8262-a66808fcb9b1/tags"/> <domain>domain.example.com</domain> <logged_in>false</logged_in> <user_name>rhevmadmin@domain.example.com</user_name> <groups> <group>Group Policy Creator Owners@domain.example.com/Users</group> <group>Domain Admins@domain.example.com/Users</group> <group>Enterprise Admins@domain.example.com/Users</group> <group>Schema Admins@domain.example.com/Users</group> <group>Administrators@domain.example.com/Builtin</group> </groups> </user> </users>
section.para: The users collection may be POSTed to in order to add an existing Active Directory user to the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager database. The client-provided new user representation must include an embedded roles list with at least one initial role to assign to the user. For example, the following request assigns two initial roles to the user joe@domain.example.com:
section.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/users HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<user> <user_name>joe@domain.example.com</user_name> <roles> <role> <name>RHEVMPowerUser</name> </role> <role id="00000000-0000-0000-0001-000000000003"/> </roles> </user>
section.para:
The new user may be identified either by Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager user ID or via the Active Directory user principal name (UPN), as in the example given above. However, the user ID format reported from the Active Directory domain may be different to the expected Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager format (for example in LDIF).
The LDAP Data Interchange Format is described in RFC 2849.
, the ID has the opposite byte order and is base-64 encoded). Hence it is usually more convenient to refer to the new user by UPN.

note.para: The user must exist a priori in the Active Directory domain, before being added to the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager database. This domain may be queried out-of-band prior to the creation being attempted.

section.para: Similarly, roles may be identified either by name or ID. Both approaches are shown in the example above.

Further roles may be attached or detached subsequently by respectively POSTing to or DELETEing from the roles sub-collection for an individual user. The example below illustrates how the RHEVMVDIUser role may be added to the role assignments for a particular user.

note.para: The embedded user roles list of the user element is only used for the initial creation, thereafter all interactions with the user's role assignments must go through the roles sub-collection.

section.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/users/225f15cd-e891-434d-8262-a66808fcb9b1/roles HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<role> <name>RHEVMVDIUser</name> </role>

note.para: Users may not be updated via the PUT verb. The only changes allowed post-creation are in the user's role assignments.

section.para: Users may be removed from the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager database via DELETE on the top level users collection. The Active Directory domain will remain unchanged after such a deletion.
